question: What does Section 2 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 define?
generated_answer: : Section 2 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 defines various terms used throughout the code, including:     Section 2(a) "bailable offence" means an offence which is shown as bailable in the First Schedule, or which is made bailable by any other law for the time being in force; and "non-bailable offence" means any other offence;    Section 2(c) "cognizable offence" means an offence for which, and "cognizable case" means a case in which, a police officer may, in accordance with the First Schedule or under any other law for the time being in force, arrest without warrant;    Section 2(h) "investigation" includes all the proceedings under this Code for the collection of evidence conducted by a police officer or by any person (other than a Magistrate) who is authorised by a Magistrate in this behalf;    Section 2(l) "non-cognizable offence" means an offence for which, and "non-cognizable case" means a case in which, a police officer has no authority to arrest without warrant.

generated_answer: : Section 3 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, clarifies how references to offenses should be understood when laws mention offenses under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) or other special or local laws. Essentially, it ensures that any powers conferred or duties imposed on officers, courts, or individuals are exercised and performed appropriately, aligning with the corresponding functions as if the CrPC provisions were directly incorporated into those other laws. This section aims to avoid ambiguity and ensure consistent application of procedural rules across different statutes dealing with offenses.

question: What is regulated under Section 4 in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
generated_answer: : Section 4 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, stipulates that all offences under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the provisions of the CrPC. Additionally, offences under any other law shall also be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the same provisions, but subject to any enactment for the time being in force regulating the manner or place of investigating, inquiring into, trying or otherwise dealing with such offences. In essence, CrPC provides the default procedure for all criminal offences in India unless a specific law dictates otherwise.
gold_answer: Trial of offences under the Indian Penal Code and other laws

question: What is the subject of Section 5 in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
generated_answer: : Section 5 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, is a saving clause. It provides that nothing in the CrPC shall affect any special or local law in force, or any special jurisdiction or power, or any special form of procedure prescribed by any other law for the time being in force.

question: What is discussed in Section 7 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
generated_answer: : Section 7 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, discusses the territorial divisions called districts and sessions divisions. It states that (1) Every State shall be a sessions division or shall consist of sessions divisions; and (2) Every sessions division shall, for the purposes of this Code, be a district or consist of districts. The State Government may, after consultation with the High Court, alter the limits or the number of such divisions and districts. The State Government may, after consultation with the High Court, divide any district into sub-divisions and may alter the limits or the number of such sub-divisions.
